metadata.name: Tic-Tac-Toe
metadata.description: A classic two-player game where players take turns marking spaces in a 3x3 grid, trying to get three in a row.

setup.description: Draw a 3x3 grid on paper or use a physical board. Decide who plays X and who plays O. X always goes first.

steps.text: Draw a 3x3 grid with 9 empty spaces
Assign X to one player and O to the other player

components.name: 3x3 Grid
components.description: A grid with 9 spaces arranged in 3 rows and 3 columns

components.name: Player Markers (X and O)
components.description: Two distinct markers for each player

phases.name: Player Turn
phases.description: On their turn, a player places their mark (X or O) in an empty space on the grid.

steps.text: Current player selects an empty space on the grid
Current player places their mark (X or O) in the selected space
Check for win condition or draw
If no win/draw, switch to the other player

actions.name: Place Mark
actions.description: Place your mark (X or O) in an empty space on the grid
effects: Your mark is placed in the selected space
Turn passes to the other player (if game not won/drawn)

scoring.description: The first player to get three of their marks in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) wins. If all spaces are filled without a winner, the game is a draw.

sources.name: Three in a Row
sources.description: Get three of your marks in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line
sources.when: Immediately upon placing the third mark in a line

tiebreakers.rule: If no player achieves three in a row and all spaces are filled, the game is a draw

endConditions.description: A player gets three of their marks in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally)
All 9 spaces are filled and no player has three in a row

edgeCases.text: A player cannot place their mark in a space that is already occupied
The game ends immediately when a player gets three in a row - no additional moves are made
Misere variant: The player who gets three in a row LOSES instead of wins
Q: Can the first player always force a win? A: No, with perfect play from both sides, Tic-Tac-Toe always results in a draw

glossary.definition: A symbol (X or O) placed by a player in a space on the grid
examples: Place your mark in an empty space

glossary.definition: Three marks of the same type (X or O) aligned horizontally, vertically, or diagonally
examples: O-O-O diagonally from top-left to bottom-right

glossary.definition: A game outcome where all spaces are filled but no player has three in a row
examples: The game ended in a draw after all 9 spaces were filled
